newsitem.title: USA: U.S. House passes scaled down national parks bill.
newsitem.headline: U.S. House passes scaled down national parks bill.

text.p: The House Saturday passed legislation to expand the national parks system after lawmakers dropped a controversial plan to let corporations become official parks sponsors.
The measure was passed 404-4 in a rare Saturday session just before the House hoped to adjourn for the year. It must now be considered by the Senate, which meets Monday, but the outlook is unclear.
President Clinton had threatened to veto the measure creating or enhancing parks in 37 states, citing the corporate sponsorship plan and other provisions.

To meet White House objections, the final bill deletes a plan to increase park entrance fees. Lawmakers also eliminated a section that would have continued a logging company's exclusive contract for timber in Alaska's Tongass National Forest.
"This is a product of bipartisan negotiations throughout many months, although it came down to the 11th hour today," said California Democratic Rep. George Miller.
"I think this will turn out to be a major gift in lands management to the people of this nation," he said.

House Resources Committee Chairman Don Young, an Alaska Republican who lost some key projects in his state, said the bill was "not everything I wanted" but praised the agreement and vowed to try again next year.

The wide-ranging legislation would establish a trust to manage the former Presidio military installation as a park in San Francisco, protect the Sterling Forest on the New York-New Jersey border and establish a tallgrass prairie reserve in Kansas.
"This bill is exactly what the American people want ... a parks bill that will ensure future generations will have pristine areas to enjoy," said New York Republican Rep. Sherwood Boehlert.

Despite the popular projects in the bill, it had became a political hot potato as environmental groups blasted its plan to let the government license corporations to be national park sponsors and use that in their advertising.
The White House, which had backed a corporate sponsorship plan to help finance the ailing parks, cited other objections to the bill earlier this week in its veto threat.
Lawmakers said they had made most of the changes the White House wanted, including eliminating boundary reductions at two Virginia parks.
The final measure does allow national flood insurance for Florida barrier islands to allow increased development, which the White House opposed.
Republicans have accused Clinton of trying to use the bill to punish his opponents.
"They gave us two days ago ... a list of 44 items that would result in a presidential veto. Every single one was in a Republican member's district," a Republican aide said.
